node.text:
The English Channel maritime traffic seen from space

Made up of images taken between 2016 and 2018 by the Copernicus Sentinel-1 satellite, this view of the English Channel shows the multitude of ships that create a two lane corridor in the narrow canal between the Atlantic Ocean and the North Sea. 
The ships appear as bright dots in the dark water, with boats that passed the English Channel in 2016 highlighted in blue, those from 2017 in green, and those from 2018 in red.

Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2016-18), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#EnglishChannel #England #UnitedKingdom #Sentinel1 #esa #Copernicus #earthobservation #Earthfromspace #satellite #space #atlanticocean #northsea #maritime #ships #boats

Nairobi seen from space
The Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission takes us over Nairobi, one of the fastest growing cities in East Africa.
 The city, visible in the centre of the image, now has a population of over three million, with the vast majority spread over 200 informal settlements.

The dark patches in the image are forests. The Ngong Forest, to the west of the city, includes exotic and indigenous trees, and hosts a variety of wild animals including wild pigs, porcupines, and dik-diks.

Copyrights contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2019), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#Nairobi #Kenya #esa #europeanspaceagency #copernicus #sentinel2 #satellite #imagesfromspace #EarthfromSpace #EarthObservation #EarthScience #earth #satelliteimages

Irminger Sea ice swirl off the coast of Greenland

The Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission takes us over a swirl of sea ice off the east coast of Greenland in the Irminger Sea, just south of the Denmark Strait between Greenland and Iceland. 
Small pieces of sea ice, known as ice floes, trace out the ocean currents beneath, resulting in a large swirl-like feature of approximately 120 km in diameter. The ice swirl is considered a typical eddy or vortex, commonly found in the summer marginal ice zone off the east coast of Greenland.

Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2019), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#IrmingerSea #Greenland #Denmarkstrait #ocean #iceswirl #ice #seaice #icefloes #Sentinel2 #esa #Copernicus #EarthObservation #EarthFromSpace #Satellite #SatelliteImages  #EarthScience

The Gulf of Finland seen from space

On Christmas Eve, the Copernicus Sentinel-1B satellite takes us  over the Gulf of Finland, with part of Finland along the top, Estonia along the bottom and Russia to the right.

The gulf is the eastern arm of the Baltic sea, stretching all the way to St Petersburg in Russia. The waters are relatively shallow, with an average depth of 38 m and a maximum of about 100 m. During winter, the waters freeze until late spring.

Copyrights contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2017), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#Finland #GulfofFinland #Estonia #Russia #balticsea #esa #europeanspaceagency #copernicus #sentinel2 #satellite #imagesfromspace #EarthfromSpace #EarthObservation #EarthScience #earth #satelliteimages

Northeast Kenya seen from space

This Copernicus Sentinel-2A satellite image features part of northeast Kenya – an area east of the East African Rift.

The region tends to be very arid and this false-colour image has been processed to highlight different types of rock, soil and sand in pinks, purples and yellows.

The bright green at the top of the image depicts vegetation, but the rest of the area appears relatively devoid of vegetation. Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2018), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO 
#Kenya #Africa #satellite #esa #copernicus #sentinel2 #earthfromspace #earthobservation  #satellite images #satellite #earthscience #europeanspaceagency

Zaragoza seen from space

This Copernicus Sentinel-2B image features the city of Zaragoza nestling in the Ebro valley and flanked by mountains to the south.

Zaragoza is the capital of the province of Zaragoza in the region of Aragon in northeast Spain. It is home to about half of Aragon’s population, making it the fifth largest municipality in Spain. In the top-right of the image, the Ebro River can be seen winding its way through the city. 
Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2018), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO 
#Spain #EbroRiver #Ebro #Zaragoza #mountains #Europe #CantabrianMountains #esa #europeanspaceagency #copernicus #sentinel2 #satellite #imagesfromspace #EarthfromSpace #EarthObservation #EarthScience #earth #satelliteimages

Lake Valencia in northern Venezuela

This false-colour image captured by the Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission shows Lake Valencia in northern Venezuela. With a surface area of 370 sq km, Lake Valencia formed a few million years ago and is now a reservoir for the cities of Valencia on the west shores and Maracay on the east shores.

This image was processed in a way that makes vegetation of the Henri Pittier National Park, north of the lake, appear in fluorescent green. These bright colours contrast with the blackness of the lake.

Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2019), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#lakevalencia #venezuela  #lake #Sentinel2 #esa #Copernicus #EarthObservation #EarthFromSpace #Satellite #SatelliteImages

Tromsø seen from space

With Christmas almost here, the red and white of this Copernicus Sentinel-2 image bring a festive feel to this week’s image featuring Tromsø – the largest city in northern Norway.

This false-colour image was processed in a way that included the near-infrared channel, which makes vegetation appear bright red. The snow over the surrounding mountains is visible in white, adding to the Christmassy feel of the image.

Most of Tromsø, lies on the island of Tromsøya, visible at the top of the image. Owing to its northerly location, the city is a popular area to experience the majestic phenomenon of the aurora borealis, or northern lights.

Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2019), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#Tromsø  #Norway #esa #europeanspaceagency #copernicus #sentinel2 #satellite #imagesfromspace #EarthfromSpace #EarthObservation #EarthScience #earth #satelliteimages

Toulouse seen from space

This Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission image shows the city of Toulouse in southern France and the surrounding agricultural landscape. 
Positioned on the banks of the River Garonne, Toulouse is also known as la Ville Rose or the pink city owing to the colour of the terracotta bricks commonly used in its architecture. The pinkish tint of the terracotta roof tiles can be seen even from space. 
Fields blanketing the countryside dominate the image. In fact, France is the EU’s leading agricultural power and is home to about a third of all agricultural land within the EU. 
Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2017), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#Toulouse #France #esa #copernicus #sentinel2 #earthfromspace #satelliteimages #earthobservation #earthscience #satellite #satelliteimages #satelliteimagery

Methane leak visible from space

Data from the Copernicus Sentinel-5P satellite revealed that an explosion in a natural gas well in Ohio in February 2018 released more than 50 000 tons of methane into the atmosphere. The blowout leaked more of this potent greenhouse gas in 20 days than the majority of many European nations do in a year from their oil and gas industries.

The findings were published in a study yesterday in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, and the study reveals the importance of using satellite data to detect and quantify pollutants such as methane. Data from the Copernicus Sentinel-5P’s Tropomi instrument revealed that 120 tons of methane were emitted per hour due to the blowout. 
The location of the explosion is marked by a black dot in the image, and shows the methane emissions before and after the blowout. The black arrow indicates the wind direction and the direction of the methane plume.

Copyrights contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2019), processed by SRON

#ohio #gasemissions #methane #greenhousegases #esa #europeanspaceagency #copernicus #sentinel5P #tropomi #satellite #imagesfromspace #EarthfromSpace #EarthObservation #EarthScience #earth #satelliteimages

Mumbai seen from space

Today, the Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission takes us over southwest India with this gorgeous image of the megacity of Mumbai, the capital of the state of Maharashtra. India’s financial and commercial heart, Mumbai is one of the largest and most densely populated urban areas in the world. Once an archipelago of seven islands, they were later united through a reclamation project during the 18th and 19th centuries.

Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2019), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#mumbai #india #maharashtra #esa #copernicus #sentinel2 #earthfromspace #satelliteimages #earthobservation #earthscience

Satellites help the MOSAiC mission see in polar winter

The Multidisciplinary drifting Observatory for the Study of Arctic Climate (or MOSAiC) expedition is the world’s largest and longest polar research expedition. A total of some 600 researchers from 20 countries will take part in different stages of it.

The expedition set sail from Tromsø, Norway In September 2019, aboard the German research icebreaker Polarstern to spend a year drifting through the Arctic Ocean – trapped in ice. This animation shows Polarstern’s route and drift as well as the growth of the winter sea ice. On board, the scientists are carrying out multiple experiments on the sea ice around the ship to better understand the impact of climate change on sea ice and the Arctic environment. 
Now facing temperatures as low as –45°C and the perpetual darkness of the polar winter, the researchers and crew remain aware of what is happening close by with the help of radar imaging satellites of Europe’s Copernicus programme, Canada, Germany and Japan.

Read more on our website: https://www.esa.int/Applications/Observing_the_Earth/Shedding_light_in_the_dark_radar_satellites_lead_the_way

Copyrights MOSAiC team/US National Snow & Ice Data Center for sea-ice extent

#MOSAiC #arctic #expedition #research #science #polarscience #icebreaker #polarstern #arcticocean #copernicus #esa #europeanspaceagency #satellites #satelliteimages #satelliteimagery #earthscience #earthobservation

North Sea bloom

This Copernicus Sentinel-3 mission image shows a significant algae bloom in the North Sea.  One of Europe's most productive fisheries, the North Sea covers an area of 570 000 sq km and is linked to the Atlantic by one of the world’s busiest shipping regions – the English Channel.

Harmful algal blooms caused by excessive growth of marine algae have occurred in the North Sea and the English Channel area in recent years, with satellite data being used to track their growth and spread. 
Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2017), processed by ESA,  CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#NorthSea #Scandinavia #algae #algaebloom #Sentinel3 #esa #Copernicus #EarthObservation #EarthFromSpace #Satellite #SatelliteImages  #EarthScience #europeanspaceagency

The Filchner-Ronne ice shelf in Antarctica 
Applying a new method, called ‘elevation edge’, to data from ESA's ice mission, CryoSat, has revealed that the entire Filchner-Ronne ice shelf, the second largest ice shelf in Antarctica, advanced by more than 800 sq km per year between 2011 and 2018. The growth of the ice shelf was only interrupted by the calving of a 120 sq km iceberg in 2012 and a few smaller-scale events.

Ice shelves are important for the stability of the ice sheet because they act as buttresses, holding back the glaciers that feed them and slowing the flow of land ice into the ocean that contributes to sea-level rise.

Copyrights ENVEO

#Antarctica #Cryosat #iceshelves #icemission #icebergs #filchnerronne #iceshelf #ice #scrience #earthexplorers #esa #earthscience #earthobservation

Gotland seen from space

In this image captured by the Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission on 20 July 2019, the streaks, eddies and whirls of the late summer algae blooms around the Baltic Sea, mixed by winds and currents, are clearly visible.

The highest concentrations of algal blooms are said to occur in the Central Baltic and around the island of Gotland, visible to the left in the image. Although algal blooms are a natural and essential part of life in the sea, human activity is also said to increase the number of annual blooms. Agricultural and industrial run-off pours fertilisers into the sea, providing additional nutrients algae need to form large blooms.

The bacteria that consume the decaying plants suck oxygen out of the water, creating dead zones where fish cannot survive. Large summer blooms can contain toxic algae that are dangerous for both humans and other animals.

Copyrights contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2019), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#gotland #sweden #balticsea #algalblooms #esa #europeanspaceagency #copernicus #sentinel2 #satellite #imagesfromspace #EarthfromSpace #EarthObservation #EarthScience #earth #satelliteimages

Greenland ice loss much faster than expected

A paper published today in Nature details how an international team of 89 polar scientists, working in collaboration with ESA and NASA, has produced the most complete picture of Greenland ice loss to date.

They estimate that Greenland lost 3.8 trillion tonnes of ice between 1992 and 2018 – enough to push global sea level up by 10.6 millimetres. Over the study period, the rate of ice loss was found to have increased seven-fold from 33 billion tonnes per year in the 1990s to 254 billion tonnes per year in the last decade.

The Ice Sheet Mass Balance Inter-comparison Exercise (IMBIE), led by Andrew Shepherd from the University of Leeds and Erik Ivins at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, compared and combined data from 11 satellites – including ESA’s ERS-1, ERS-2, Envisat and CryoSat missions, as well as the EU’s Copernicus Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 missions – to monitor changes in the ice sheet’s volume, flow and gravity.

Copyrights Planetary Visions (credit: ESA/NASA/IMBIE/Planetary Visions)

#greenland #esa #NASA #universityofleeds #iceloss #datascience #science #dataset #earthobservation #satellites #earthscience #envisat #cryosat #earthexplorers #copernicus #sentinel1 #sentinel2

Viti Levu, Fiji, seen from space

This Copernicus Sentinel-2B satellite shows the Republic of Fiji in the South Pacific Ocean. Part of Fiji’s largest island, Viti Levu, is pictured here, with coral reefs speckling the water. Shaped by volcanic activity and earthquakes, the centre of the island is dominated by forests and a mountain range. The highest peak, Mount Tomanivi, reaches over 1320 m.

Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2017), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#fiji #vitilevu #island #coralreef #pacificocean #ocean #Sentinel2 #esa #Copernicus #EarthObservation #EarthFromSpace #Satellite #SatelliteImages #EarthScience

New biomass map to take stock of the world’s carbon

The first of a series of global maps aimed at quantifying change in carbon stored as biomass across the world’s forests and shrublands has been released today by ESA’s Climate Change Initiative at COP25 – the United Nation Climate Change Conference currently taking place in Madrid.

Satellite data was used to create a map of above-ground Biomass for 2017-18. The new map uses optical, lidar and radar data acquired in 2017 and 2018 from multiple Earth observation satellites, and is the first to integrate multiple acquisitions from the Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission and Japan’s ALOS mission.

Copyrights biomass_cci project funded under ESA's Climate Change Initiative

#esa #copernicus #europeanspaceagency #sentinel1 #alos #japan #satellite #satellites #satellitedata #carbon #biomass #worldmap #globalmap #globaldatasets #maps #earthscience #earthobservation #science #cop25 #madrid #climatechange #esaclimate

East Bali in Indonesia seen from space

This Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission image shows the island of Bali, one of the 27 provinces of Indonesia. Indonesia has more volcanoes than any other country in the world, owing to its position on the Pacific Ring of Fire. 
Dotted with clouds, Mount Seraya is visible on the peninsula that juts to the east. Its volcanic rocks creates a rugged terrain, but is surrounded by lush vegetation. 
Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2018), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#Bali #Indonesia #Sentinel2 #esa #Copernicus #EarthObservation #EarthFromSpace #EarthScience #Satellite #SatelliteImages

The Gulf of Taranto in southern Italy

The Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission takes us over the Gulf of Taranto, located on the inner heel of southern Italy. Taranto, an important coastal city, is visible on the bottom-right of the image. Founded by a Greek colony in the 8th Century BC, the city is now an important commercial port. 
Along the coast, the Aleppo pine forest of the Stornara Nature Reserve is clearly visible in dark green, taking its name from the many starlings that migrate there during winter. The reserve was founded in 1977 and covers an area of approximately 1500 hectares.

Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2019), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#taranto #italy #gulfoftaranto #gulf #stornaranaturereserve #Sentinel2 #esa #Copernicus #EarthObservation #EarthScience  #EarthFromSpace #Satellite #SatelliteImages #EarthScience

Mato Grosso in Brazil

Today, the Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission takes us over part of the Brazilian state of Mato Grosso deep in the Amazon interior.

This image combines three separate radar images from the Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission taken about two years apart to show changes in crops and land cover over time. Here, the first image, from 2 May 2015, is picked out in blue; the second, from 16 March 2017, picks out changes in green; and the third from 18 March 2019 in red; areas in grey depict little or no change between 2015 and 2019.

Much of the tropical forest in Mato Grosso has been cut down and given over to farming. Although the state has one of the highest historical rates of deforestation in the Amazonian Brazil, deforestation is slowing and Mato Grosso is now said to be a global leader in climate-change solutions. 
Credits: contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2015, 2017, 2019), processed by ESA

#brazil #matogrosso #amazonforest #deforestation #esa #europeanspaceagency #copernicus #sentinel1 #satellite #imagesfromspace #EarthfromSpace #EarthObservation #EarthScience #earth #satelliteimages

Lena River Delta in Russia

This Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission false-colour image shows the Lena River Delta in Russia, the largest delta in the Arctic. At nearly 4500 km long, the Lena River is one of the longest rivers in the world. The delta’s snow-covered tundra is frozen for most of the year, before thawing and blossoming into a fertile wetland during the brief polar summer – a 32 000 sq km haven for Arctic wildlife. In 1995, the Lena Delta Reserve was expanded, making it the largest protected area in Russia.

Copyright contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data (2019), processed by ESA, CC BY-SA 3.0 IGO

#lenariver #lenadelta #russia #arctic #wetland #delta #river #lenadeltareserve #Sentinel1 #esa #Copernicus #EarthObservation #EarthFromSpace #EarthScience #Satellite #SatelliteImages
